cs.CL, cs.SI, cs.IR, cs.LG, cs.CY 

This paper is likely to belong to the arXiv CS sub-category of cs.CL (Computation and Language) as it deals with sentiment and emotion analysis, which is a subfield of natural language processing. Additionally, the paper mentions using news articles as a source of data, which is a common domain for research in this sub-category. 

It could also belong to cs.SI (Social and Information Networks) as the paper mentions using crowd-sourced affective annotation from readers of news articles. 

cs.IR (Information Retrieval) is another likely sub-category as the paper discusses the use of social media data for affective lexicon building, which involves retrieving and analyzing large amounts of text data. 

cs.LG (Machine Learning) is a possible sub-category as the paper mentions using a na\""{\i}ve approach for regression and classification tasks, which are common machine learning tasks. 

Finally, cs.CY (Computers and Society) is a less likely sub-category, but it could be relevant as the paper discusses the ethical implications of using crowd-sourced data for affective lexicon building.
